name: Blackfoot
place: Northern Great Plains of North America
description: The Blackfoot is an Algonquian-speaking tribe living in the northern Great Plains of North America. This sky culture has 4 constellation line figures, and names for the Milky Way, the Pleiades, the Orion Nebula, three planets and three stars. This data is a transcript of the broad survey of North-American astronomical traditions in the book Stars of the first people: Native American star myths and constellations [miller1997stars] (from page 243). The basic information is not collected by this recent author. It is attributed to anthropologists from the early 1900s: Mythology of the Blackfoot Indians published in 1908 [wissler1908mythology], and `The old north trail, or, Life, legends and religion of the Blackfeet Indians` published in 1910 [mcclintock1910old]. Source [miller1997stars] instead collects the data and draws the constellations explicitly, based on this early information. According to the sources, the Blackfoot often featured the Big Dipper, the Pleiades, and the Morning Star on their tipis, and believe that when people die, their spirits go into the sky and become stars, ever increasing the number of stars in the heavens. The sources include many associated star stories (not transcribed here), and mostly English names. Another constellation called Hand in the Sky has been documented, but was not identified (so is not in this dataset). It could be another name for the Spider Man's Fingers, or another constellation entirely. An associated story also explains a particular tipi design.

constellations.certainty: The source doesn't explicitly provide the constellation lines, but identifies it with the modern Big Dipper, as a bowl with a handle.
constellations.description: Represents siblings who escape to the sky when being chased by a bear. The sister is the small star Alcor in this version. In a second version of this constellation (not included separately here), the youngest brother becomes the North Star, and the sister (who used to carry him) is the pointer star at the lip of the bowl. This constellation was used for time-keeping before the introduction of clocks.
Represents twins whose story explains how a particular tipi design came into use.

constellations.certainty: Identification is uncertain. This is a possible configuration of stars in Hercules by [miller1997stars], based on the quote 'the five bright stars just beyond [the Northern Crown] in the constellation of Hercules are his five fingers' [mcclintock1910old].
constellations.description: Represents five fingers spinning a thread to let the legendary Feather Woman (native name: So-at-sa-ki) down from the sky.
Represents the stones laid in a circle which used to hold down a tipi.

* alf UMi.description: The other stars walk around it.

NAME Pleiades.description: Represent six poor children and have an associated story which explains why they are visible in the evening sky only from fall to spring, but not the rest of the year.

NAME Jupiter.description: A story explains that The Morning Star is the Young Morning Star's father, and sometimes they travel together, but they may also travel apart for many years. At the time when this story was documented (in July 1905), they were in conjunction.

NAME Milky Way.description: Represents the shortest path from the sky to the earth.

NAME Orion Nebula.description: Represents the stone knife of the mythical person Blood-Clot, a culture hero who rids the world of evil.
